description: dark red ground; three flying gold cranes on one side; gold waves on back; tan silk cord
inscription: in gold: 応需抱一筆 {ōju Hōitsu hitsu}; red seal: 文詮 {Bunsen}
signed: in gold: 羊遊斎 {Yōyūsai} and red kao
text: Animals and insects come to life on these personal objects, some small enough to fit in one’s hands, and bring good luck to its owner. Since the 800s, the Japanese have developed and perfected a way to layer metals, shells, and other natural pigments to create designs on lacquer, a type of resin extracted from Japanese sumac. Lacquerware is not only beautiful but also durable and thus was used for a variety of objects, both utilitarian and fanciful.
title: Four-case inro decorated with flying cranes after a design by Sakai Hōitsu
